subject: RE: [junit] Programmer Tests and the Database
msgSnippet: Andy wrote: Our Java app was developed and tested on Windows, using an mySql database. Now, during our testing on linux, suddenly our app stopped working.
messageBody:
Andy wrote:
Our Java app was developed and tested on Windows, using an mySql database.
Now, during our testing on linux, suddenly our app stopped working. Turns
out our embedded SQL statement had a mixture of case for table and column
names. This case mixture wasn't a problem on windows, but is on linux.

My opinions:
1.This can also happen, when you put
all the SQL in the resource bundle.
2.Embedded SQL (Oracle: Pro C/C++ or SQLJ) is ugly.
Your code is getting littered with machine generated junk.
Use OCI or JDBC.
3. Even if you have all the SQL in the resource bundle,
there is usually a need to modify the statements dynamically at
runtime in your Java code.
4. I also worked successfully with SQL in the resource bundle.
But the dynamic modification had to take place in the Java/C++
code. So why not incorporate the SQL templates in the
java code. Moreover this requires less discipline than
putting the SQL templates in the resource bundle. Therefore
it is more likely, that this coding guideline is getting obeyed.

Just my 2 cents
